Line 28: Line 28:
Spalding grew up in the [[King, Portland, Oregon|King neighborhood]] of [[Portland, Oregon]],<ref name=BancudM-TPT-2001-12-14>Bancud, Michaela (December 14, 2001). - "Esperanza in the Wings". - ''[[Portland Tribune]]''.</ref> a neighborhood she describes as "[[ghetto]]" and "pretty scary".<ref name=Jazzreview>Symister-Masterson, Cheryl K., (September 2006). - [http://www.jazzreview.com/article/review-4970.html "Esperanza Spalding: It's Natural"]. - ''[[Jazz Review]]''.</ref> Her mother, who raised her and her brother as a single parent, was an independent, industrious woman.<ref name=official>[http://esperanzaspalding.com/ "Biography"]. - Esperanza Spalding Official Web Site.</ref>
Spalding grew up in the [[King, Portland, Oregon|King neighborhood]] of [[Portland, Oregon]],<ref name=BancudM-TPT-2001-12-14>Bancud, Michaela (December 14, 2001). - "Esperanza in the Wings". - ''[[Portland Tribune]]''.</ref> a neighborhood she describes as "[[ghetto]]" and "pretty scary".<ref name=Jazzreview>Symister-Masterson, Cheryl K., (September 2006). - [http://www.jazzreview.com/article/review-4970.html "Esperanza Spalding: It's Natural"]. - ''[[Jazz Review]]''.</ref> Her mother, who raised her and her brother as a single parent, was an independent, industrious woman.<ref name=official>[http://esperanzaspalding.com/ "Biography"]. - Esperanza Spalding Official Web Site.</ref>
â
Spalding is of [[African-American]], [[Welsh]] and [[Mexican]] descent,<ref>RamÃ­rez, Deborah (August 14, 2008). - "Touching Bass - Jazz Phenom Sings, Plays and Talks Norah Jones". - ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''.</ref> and describes this as a diverse ethnic heritage that includes "Welsh, Hispanic, and Native American roots in addition to the unidentified roots from Africa".<ref name=Jazzreview/>
+
Spalding is of [[African-American]], [[Welsh]] and [[Spanish people|Spanish]] descent,<ref>RamÃ­rez, Deborah (August 14, 2008). - "Touching Bass - Jazz Phenom Sings, Plays and Talks Norah Jones". - ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''.</ref> and describes this as a diverse ethnic heritage that includes "Welsh, Hispanic, and Native American roots in addition to the unidentified roots from Africa".<ref name=Jazzreview/>
Her black roots come from her father: "My mom is Welsh, Hispanic, and Native American, and my father is black."<ref name="X-Factor BassPlayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.bassplayer.com/article/only-24-jazz/may-08/35479|title=At Only 24, Jazz Phenom Esperanza Spalding Has The Ultimate âX-Factorâ|last=Booth|first=Philip|year=2009|work=''Bass Player'' magazine|publisher=New Bay Media, LLC.|accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref>
Her black roots come from her father: "My mom is Welsh, Hispanic, and Native American, and my father is black."<ref name="X-Factor BassPlayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.bassplayer.com/article/only-24-jazz/may-08/35479|title=At Only 24, Jazz Phenom Esperanza Spalding Has The Ultimate âX-Factorâ|last=Booth|first=Philip|year=2009|work=''Bass Player'' magazine|publisher=New Bay Media, LLC.|accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref>
Her Hispanic roots trace through her mother, a native of [[Southern California]], who indirectly educated Spalding in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]] by hiring a [[Cuba]]n [[nanny]].<ref name=PCOLPopmatters>Morales, Ed (June 23, 2008). - [http://www.popmatters.com/pm/article/esperanza-spaldings-debut-picks-up-where-jazz-fusion-of-the-1970s-left-off "Esperanza Spalding's debut picks up where jazz fusion of the 1970s left off"]. - ''Pop Matters''.</ref> Spalding notes that these influences, along with many other factors in her life, have come together to shape her into who she is.<ref name=PCOLPopmatters/> She also has an interest in other cultures, including [[Brazil]],<ref name=CarpenterE-TNYT-2008-07-27>Carpenter, Ellen (July 27, 2008). - [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/27/fashion/27nite.html Up to Her Ears: A Night Out with Esperanza Spalding"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> and respects the artistry inherent in language, commenting specifically, "With [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] songs the phrasing of the melody is intrinsically linked with the language, and itâs beautiful".<ref name=Booth>{{cite web |url=http://www.bassplayer.com/article/esperanza-spalding/dec-06/24264 |title=Esperanza Spalding |accessdate=2008-06-13 |last=Booth |first=Philip |year=2006 |month=December |work=Bass Player }}</ref>
Her Hispanic roots trace through her mother, a native of [[Southern California]], who indirectly educated Spalding in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]] by hiring a [[Cuba]]n [[nanny]].<ref name=PCOLPopmatters>Morales, Ed (June 23, 2008). - [http://www.popmatters.com/pm/article/esperanza-spaldings-debut-picks-up-where-jazz-fusion-of-the-1970s-left-off "Esperanza Spalding's debut picks up where jazz fusion of the 1970s left off"]. - ''Pop Matters''.</ref> Spalding notes that these influences, along with many other factors in her life, have come together to shape her into who she is.<ref name=PCOLPopmatters/> She also has an interest in other cultures, including [[Brazil]],<ref name=CarpenterE-TNYT-2008-07-27>Carpenter, Ellen (July 27, 2008). - [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/27/fashion/27nite.html Up to Her Ears: A Night Out with Esperanza Spalding"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> and respects the artistry inherent in language, commenting specifically, "With [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] songs the phrasing of the melody is intrinsically linked with the language, and itâs beautiful".<ref name=Booth>{{cite web |url=http://www.bassplayer.com/article/esperanza-spalding/dec-06/24264 |title=Esperanza Spalding |accessdate=2008-06-13 |last=Booth |first=Philip |year=2006 |month=December |work=Bass Player }}</ref>
